wikipedia_page.main: Harold Smith was an English professional rugby league footballer who played in the 1920s. He played at representative level for Great Britain and England, and at club level for Bradford Northern and Halifax, as a hooker, i.e. number 9, during the era of contested scrums.

response: * Herbert Smith won caps for England while at Halifax in 1927 against Wales, and won caps for Great Britain while at Bradford Northern in 1926-27 against New Zealand (2 matches)

response: * Herbert Smith circa-1926

Charles Herbert Smith (13 February 1909 – 10 April 1976) was a New Zealand rugby union and professional rugby league footballer who played in the 1930s and 1940s. He played representative level rugby union (RU) for New Zealand (Heritage № 406) (non-test matches), South Island and Otago (captain), and at club level for Southern RFC , as a centre, i.e. number 12 or 13, switching codes in 1936. He played representative level rugby league (RL) for British Empire XIII, and at club level for Streatham and Mitcham and Halifax (Heritage № 437), as a , or , i.e. number 2 or 5, or, 3 or 4.

Herbert Smith (birth registered third ¼ 1915 – death uncertain) was an English professional rugby league footballer who played in the 1930s and 1940s. He played at club level for Batley Shamrocks, Castleford (Heritage № 145), Bramley, Batley (World War II guest), and Bradford Northern, as a , or , i.e. number 2 or 5, 3 or 4, 8 or 10, or 11 or 12, during the era of contested scrums.David Smart & Andrew Howard (1 July 2000) "Images of Sport - Castleford Rugby League - A Twentieth Century History". The History Press Ltd.  Herbert Smith served with army during World War II, in 1944 he was selected for the R.L. Services XV, but was unable to play due to training for the Normandy landings.
Herbert Smith's birth was registered in Dewsbury, West Riding of Yorkshire, England.

Herbert Smith played right-, i.e. number 10, in Bradford Northern's 8-4 victory over Leeds in the 1946–47 Challenge Cup Final during the 1946–47 season at Wembley Stadium, London on Saturday 3 May 1947, in front of a crowd of 77,605.

Herbert Smith made his dêbut for Castleford as a left-, i.e. number 4, on Monday 8 April 1935, he played as a , i.e. number 5, on Saturday 13 April 1935, and he played his last match for Castleford as a right-, i.e. number 3, on Saturday 27 April 1935.
Herbert Smith is the son of the  of the 1910s for Dewsbury, Mick Smith.
